026package com.ibm.streams.operator.samples.operators;
027
028import com.ibm.streams.operator.AbstractOperator;
029import com.ibm.streams.operator.OperatorContext;
030import com.ibm.streams.operator.OperatorContext.ContextCheck;
031import com.ibm.streams.operator.OutputTuple;
032import com.ibm.streams.operator.StreamingInput;
033import com.ibm.streams.operator.StreamingOutput;
034import com.ibm.streams.operator.Tuple;
035import com.ibm.streams.operator.Type.MetaType;
036import com.ibm.streams.operator.compile.OperatorContextChecker;
037import com.ibm.streams.operator.model.InputPortSet;
038import com.ibm.streams.operator.model.InputPorts;
039import com.ibm.streams.operator.model.OutputPortSet;
040import com.ibm.streams.operator.model.OutputPorts;
041import com.ibm.streams.operator.model.PrimitiveOperator;
042
043/**
044 * Simple class that maintains an per-input port int64 sequence number for
045 * arriving tuples and sets it as the portSequence attribute of the
046 * output tuple. This class is to demonstrate synchronization on a
047 * per-port basis. Each incoming tuple is assigned to an output port
048 * at the same index using OutputTuple.assign(), that is the code
049 * assumes there are N input ports and N output ports.
050 * <BR>
051 * The portSequence attribute value corresponds to order arrival of the
052 * tuples to the process method, there is no guarantee that this operator
053 * will submit tuples in the portSequence order. See PortSequencer.process()
054 * for details.
055 */
056@PrimitiveOperator(description=
057    "Operator that maintains an per-input port `int64` sequence number for arriving tuples and sets it as the `portSequence` attribute of the output tuple.",
058        comment=PortSequencer.IBM_Teracloud_ApS_COPYRIGHT)
059@InputPorts(@InputPortSet)
060@OutputPorts(@OutputPortSet)
061public class PortSequencer extends AbstractOperator {
062    
063    /**
064     * Array of sequence number for the tuples for each port.
065     */
066    private long[] portSequences;
067    
068    @ContextCheck
069    public static void checkPorts(OperatorContextChecker checker) {
070        final OperatorContext context = checker.getOperatorContext();
071        
072        // Verify the number of output ports is the same as
073        // the input ports.
074        if (context.getNumberOfStreamingOutputs() != context.getNumberOfStreamingInputs()) {
075            checker.setInvalidContext(
076                    "Number of output ports {0} must match the number of input ports {1}.",
077                    new Object[] {context.getNumberOfStreamingOutputs(),
078                            context.getNumberOfStreamingInputs()});
079        }
080        
081        // Verify that each output port has a int64 portSequence attribute
082        for (StreamingOutput<?> port : context.getStreamingOutputs()) {
083            checker.checkRequiredAttributes(port, "portSequence");
084            checker.checkAttributeType(
085                    port.getStreamSchema().getAttribute("portSequence"), MetaType.INT64);
086          }
087    }
088
089    /**
090     * Initialize the portSequences field holding the Operator's (this)
091     * synchronization to ensure later threads fetching it using
092     * getPortSequences() are guaranteed to see the initialized value.
093     */
094    @Override
095    public synchronized void initialize(OperatorContext context) throws Exception {
096        super.initialize(context);
097        portSequences = new long[context.getNumberOfStreamingInputs()];
098    }
099
100    /**
101     * Get the portSequences instance field using synchronization.
102     * The synchronization (on this) guarantees the reader will see
103     * the initialized value. Accessing the field directly does not
104     * guarantee a thread will see the initialized value due to the
105     * visibility rules defined by the Java Memory model.
106     * @return the portSequences
107     */
108    private synchronized long[] getPortSequences() {
109        return portSequences;
110    }
111
112    /**
113     * Process a tuple simply assigning it to the output port
114     * with the same index and adding the portSequence field
115     * set to the sequence of the arriving tuple within the port.
116     * <P>
117     * Synchronization is on the StreamingInput object
118     * corresponding to the port the tuple arrived on. This per-port
119     * synchronization allows threads processing tuples from different
120     * input ports to concurrently calculate their own port sequence value.
121     * </P>
122     * <P>
123     * Note that the order submission of tuples is <b>not</b>
124     * guaranteed by this method since no lock is held between the
125     * assignment of portSequence and the submission of the tuple.
126     * Thus, for example, after one thread has portSequence=100
127     * another thread may grab portSequence=101 and this '101' thread
128     * may call submit() before the '100' thread.
129     * </P>
130     */
131    @Override
132    public void process(StreamingInput<Tuple> port, Tuple tuple)
133       throws Exception {
134        
135        /*
136         * Synchronize the port sequence on the StreamingInput
137         * reference for the port the tuple arrives on. Note
138         * the synchronization is only held to calculate and
139         * set the portSequence to reduce contention by making
140         * the critical section as small as possible.
141         */
142        long portSequence;
143        synchronized (port) {         
144            portSequence = getPortSequences()[port.getPortNumber()]++;
145        }
146        
147        StreamingOutput<OutputTuple> outPort = getOutput(port.getPortNumber());
148        
149        OutputTuple outTuple = outPort.newTuple();
150        
151        outTuple.assign(tuple);
152        outTuple.setLong("portSequence", portSequence);
153        
154        // No synchronization held during submission.
155        getOutput(port.getPortNumber()).submit(outTuple);
156    }
157}
